Topic.Title: Obama's big tax increase on the rich is a BIG JOKE ....

Message.Msg: Sadly, Mixti is still all mixtied up about the inverse correlation between tax rates and tax revenues. Increase rates = decrease tax revenues. You tax something, you get less of it. It's really as simple as that. There is, however, a balance to be struck. If you tax nothing, you may get so much of it that it creates a different problem. But the idea that somehow, there are a handful of envious Obama votards (yes, new term) who now feel comfortable thinking that "higher rates = punishment for rich = I feel better" is really an appalling commentary on the incredible, yet provable ignorance of Obama votards. The reality of this failed tax-the-rich policy is quite different. The economic equation for this policy is: higher rates = higher deferred income = less disposable income = more saving = less spent in economy = marginally more people not receiving economic benefit of spending = policy accomplishes nothing = politicians pat themselves on back & receive campaign contributions = bankruptcy of country unavoidable = more votards look for next Obamoron = wealthy depart country with wealth intact (ref. France).

Topic.Title: You ignorant people don't understand, including the right wing radio hosts, that we are not inflating

Message.Msg: As soon as the US credit rating is downgraded again, and it will under Obama, then the dollar gets the boot as the reserve currency. When that happens, the jig is up and we turn into a bigger, more complicated, more f--d up version of Greece. Keynsian economics was intended for short term government intervention during a crisis such as a depression, not a long term formula for running the world's leading economy. Liberals like yourself love to use Keynes as an excuse for reckless spending but it is not sustainable and was never meant to be.

Message.Title: How the Obama Administration continues to destroy America and flaunts the law..continuously.
Message.Msg: By law, each April and October, federal agencies are required to release an accounting of proposed regulations that will have an economically significant impact. That didn't happen in 2012. Instead, the Obama administration didn't release its 2012 regulatory agenda until on the Friday before Christmas. "The fact that this snuck in after the election, during the holiday season when people were otherwise occupied with their families, is not surprising," said John Malcolm, senior legal fellow at the Heritage Foundation's Center for Legal and Judicial Studies. Since the Dec. 21 release, legal experts and analysts have been pouring through the tens of thousands of pages in order to determine their impact. According to an initial estimate by the American Action Forum, which notes that some entries are missing key fiscal data, the cost of implementing the agenda would top $123 billion. Completing the paperwork could require more than 13 million man-hours. "It's massive," former Deputy Attorney General Tom Dupree said. "There's no way any human being can sit down and read this whole thing from front to back."

Topic.Title: Day 3 of $12 resistance fight?

Message.Msg: Samm: Agreed. When in doubt (trading-wise) tis best to sit on one's hands, eh? It looks like it's consolidating position as a function of time. If you go back and look at a 60 day chart you can see it did this, more or less, at $9.80, $10.60 and ~$11.50. I'd like to think the outcome of this sideways function will be the same as the prior three. But I need a set-up confirmation before hitting the trade. Let's see what happens. Topic.Title: Intrest on 16 Trillion in debt going to skyrocket with higher intrest rates

Message.Msg: Actually if interest rates go up it is good for the $16 Trillion of debt we have. If you understand that US debt is just outstanding treasuries and those treasuries have been issued at historically low interest rates in the past few years, you would be hoping for rates to go up. If rates go up, then the prices of bonds go down, especially those bonds with lower interest rates, which will make it cheaper for the US to buy back its own debt.

Message.Title: Do people see parallelism now between HFT's, computer algo trading used on AAPL and now BAC?
Message.Msg: Remember how the lack of an uptick rule was easily overcome in the stock of Apple over a year's time untl it reached 700 dollars, then the rug was pulled out and AAPL is now in the low 500's. You did not fight the market makers in that one while it was rising. Do you see the same thing here with BAC's climb from Buffett's area of getting his shares in the low 7's with a steady rise started right after the Presidential election to the 12 dollar region now? Pete Najarian said last month that he sees BAC going to at least 12 dollars. Cramer last night on Mad Money said he sees BAC going to 16. Strange thing is though that here BAC is at 12 and Cramer doesn't have it in his Charitable Trust yet at this time. That is strange. So, what I am saying is that now with computer driven algo and High Frequency Trading systems like the one that Goldman Sachs said one of their people stole the source code? and they then wanted them imprisoned for doing so...is that now much more important than having an uptick rule? Can these billion dollar systems take a stock and make it go where "they" want it to go...up or down? Has the stock market divorced itself from the economy now since there is High Frequency Trading and Computer driven algos in use as the former Assistant Treasury Secretary for Ronald Reagan recently said, Dr. Craig Roberts? DYODD JMHO

Topic.Title: Do people see parallelism now between HFT's, computer algo trading used on AAPL and now BAC?

Message.Msg: With the likes of IBM's Watson around, as well as Deep Blue and Deep Thought, these stock market runners better be careful because I gave up a long time ago trying to beat a more recent computer chess game on the higher difficulty level settings (not even big time like those two IBM chess computers). The stock market now reminds me of the fast paced video games like William's Defender where it was critical to decide whether it had been set on its highest setting or a normal setting. Normal setting would eat most people's quarters in about 10 seconds. High setting would eat all three lives in four or five seconds. I ended up getting good at it and could playing 6 hours or more obtaining millions of points on the normal to moderately high setting. On the top level I could only last about 2.5 hours. I was lucky I didn't have a stroke at the time. If they let it slip out that they can take a stock and make it go almost anywhere for a few months to a year or so, no matter what the true supply and demand of the market participants is, then it's all she wrote for this investment avenue or "game". I am getting tired. It's time to let the humans back in control of the market. DYODD JMHO

Topic.Title: Is it time to sell BAC before AA earnings? Also, BAC is already up too much. I guess is way over bought.

Message.Msg: This is not overbought for the simple fact that it's not spectulators that are buying it up but institutions that are shifting from bonds into equities. Since financials are set to outperform in a recovery, they are being overweighted. Buying programs try to minimize impact to prices by focusing their buying at the end of each trading day. What we are seeing is probably a climb to $20 and beyond this year. Remember, Paulson felt the stock was worth $30 before he eventually capitulated. Buying calls with the cheap implied volatility is like printing money on your computer. I netted close to a million in just a month. I plan to sell some other assets and double down on jan 15 calls.

Message.Title: BofA in Talks to Sell Some Mortgage Servicing Rights
Message.Msg: This out on the wire at 15:56: Bank of America Corp. (BAC) is in talks to sell servicing rights on about $300 billion in mortgages, Reuters reported Friday, citing two people familiar with the situation. Ocwen Financial Corp. (OCN), Nationstar Mortgage Holdings Inc. (NSM) and Walter Investment Management Corp. (WAC) are among those in talks with Bank of America, Reuters reported. A Bank of America spokesman told Reuters that the company does not comment on "market rumor or speculation.

Topic.Title: Obama's big tax increase on the rich is a BIG JOKE ....

Message.Msg: So, in your Alice-in-Wonderland view, even though the tax increase will result in a larger deficit, you have invested yourself completely in the approach because it is "fair". If you simply understood math, you would see how that isn't so. If a person pays more dollars in taxes, that should suit your redistributionist policy goals. But they won't. At the higher rates, they'll pay less because they'll do the activities that generate tax bills less. Fact of life. Maybe not on the other side of the looking glass where the votards live, but fact nonetheless. Now how, exactly, is it fair that you feel justified in punishing for fairness when the only person punished is YOU??? YOU are the one who will be saddled with the debt, the unemployment, the soup lines, not that guy who pays the 39% of all taxes collected even at the lower "Bush" tax rate. I would love to hear your definition of fairness without you resorting to this kind of masochism.

Message.Title: Workers making $30,000 will take a bigger hit on their pay than those earning $500,000 under new fiscal deal
Message.Msg: Middle-class workers will take a bigger hit to their income proportionately than those earning between $200,000 and $500,000 under the new fiscal cliff deal, according to the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center. Earners in the latter group will pay an average 1.3 percent more - or an additional $2,711 - in taxes this year, while workers making between $30,000 and $200,000 will see their paychecks shrink by as much as 1.7 percent - or up to $1,784 - the D.C.-based think tank reported. Overall, nearly 80 percent of households will pay more money to the federal government as a result of the fiscal cliff deal. Read more: http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2256972/Middle-earners-hit-hardest-revealed-workers-making-30-000-bigger-hit-earning-500-000-new-fiscal-deal.html#ixzz2H3MKIfCQ Follow us: @MailOnline on Twitter | DailyMail on Facebook

Message.Title: Taxpayer Bill for Obama’s Hawaii Vacations: $20 Million
Message.Msg: The total cost to taxpayers of Obama’s vacations to Hawaii since becoming president is likely in excess of $20 million, and possibly much, much more. During a time of budget deficits that threaten the nation’s security and its future, the Obamas have chosen to maintain a “family tradition” and vacation halfway around the world instead of finding far cheaper alternatives closer to home. The $20 million figure is based on estimates of the cost of the four Hawaii vacations the Obamas have taken during Christmastime 2009-2012. According to a detailed breakdown by the Hawaii Reporter, the annual excursions in 2009, 2010, and 2011 cost about $4 million, much of it attributable to the expense of taking Air Force One, at an hour rate of about $180,000, on an eighteen-hour roundtrip journey to Honolulu and back.

Topic.Title: Specific date foe stress test?

Message.Msg: The ability to raise a dividend or do a share buyback depends on the stress test results. Anything you see about those issues prior to the resuts will be speculation, which could be dead on or just b.s. Last year the results were announced to everyone (public and banks) pretty much at the same time.
